title: Topical repellents for malaria prevention
authors: Gabaldón Figueira, JC; Wagah, MG; Adipo, LB; Wanjiku, C; Maia, MF

response.output:
What can topical repellents do to stop malaria when other mosquito control methods are used?

Key Messages
- Topical repellents may slightly lower the chance of getting malaria and having malaria symptoms, but the evidence is weak and not clear when used together with other mosquito‑control tools.
- The use of repellents is very safe; only a few people had mild skin irritation.
- More research, especially in refugee camps and with individual‑level studies, is needed to know if repellents really help.

What is malaria and why is it a problem?
Malaria is a disease spread by mosquitoes that bite people and can make them very sick. It is common in many parts of the world and can be deadly if not treated.

What are topical repellents and how might they help?
Topical repellents are creams or sprays that you put on your skin. They keep mosquitoes away from the skin, so the mosquitoes are less likely to bite you.

What did we want to find out?
We wanted to see if using topical repellents alone or together with other mosquito‑control methods, like bed nets or indoor spraying, can reduce how many people get malaria in areas where malaria is common.

What did we do?
We looked for studies that compared people who used repellents with people who did not, and we combined the results to see the overall effect.

What did we find?
Study characteristics
We found eight studies that met our criteria. Six of these studies were large enough to be combined in a main analysis. The studies were carried out in many countries and included people of all ages, including groups that are at higher risk such as refugees, forest workers, and soldiers.

Main results
When we looked at all the studies together, the evidence suggests that repellents may slightly reduce the number of people who get malaria and the number of people who develop malaria symptoms. The evidence is not strong, so we are not sure how big the benefit is.

The evidence also suggests that repellents may slightly lower the overall number of people who have malaria parasites in their blood. Again, the evidence is weak.

Safety
Very few people who used repellents had mild skin irritation. No serious problems were reported.

What are the limitations of the evidence?
We have little confidence in the evidence because the studies were not all designed the same way and some may have had problems that could affect the results. The studies were also very varied in how they were carried out, and many of them were small or had missing information. Because of these issues, we cannot be sure how well repellents work.

How up to date is this evidence?
The evidence is up to date to January 2023.
